slides.title: Exploring Science: How We Discover the World

content.subtitle: Understanding How Scientists Think and Work

slides.notes: Welcome to today's exploration of science. We'll discover not just what scientists know, but how they come to know it. Science is fundamentally about asking questions and finding evidence-based answers.

slides.title: What is Science?
slides.notes: Science is more than memorizing facts. It's a way of thinking critically about the world. Every scientific claim must be supported by evidence that others can verify and replicate.

slides.title: The Scientific Method

content.definition: A systematic approach to investigating phenomena, acquiring new knowledge, and correcting previous errors through observation and experimentation.

slides.notes: The scientific method isn't always linear. Scientists often cycle back through steps as they refine their understanding. The key is that every step must be documented and reproducible.

slides.title: Types of Science
slides.notes: While we categorize sciences for convenience, modern research often crosses these boundaries. Climate science, for example, combines chemistry, physics, biology, and earth science.

slides.title: Why Science Matters
slides.notes: From the vaccines protecting public health to the smartphones in your pocket, science shapes every aspect of modern life. Scientific literacy helps you make informed decisions as citizens and consumers.

slides.title: Thinking Like a Scientist

callouts.heading: Stay Curious
callouts.text: Ask 'why' and 'how' about everything you observe in the world around you.

callouts.heading: Embrace Uncertainty
callouts.text: Good scientists say 'I don't know yet' and see it as an opportunity to learn.

callouts.heading: Avoid Bias
callouts.text: Don't let what you expect to find influence what you actually observe.

slides.notes: Critical thinking is the foundation of scientific inquiry. Scientists must constantly question their assumptions and be willing to change their minds when evidence demands it.

slides.title: Famous Discoveries
slides.notes: These discoveries didn't happen overnight. Each required years of dedicated work, countless failures, and often collaboration across many scientists. Science is a cumulative, communal endeavor.

slides.title: Science by the Numbers
slides.notes: These numbers represent centuries of scientific investigation. Each fact was once unknown, discovered through careful observation and experimentation.

slides.title: Try It Yourself!
slides.notes: Science isn't something that only happens in laboratories. You can practice scientific thinking every day by observing, questioning, and testing your ideas about the world.

slides.title: Questions and Review
slides.notes: Let's open the floor for questions. Think about how you might apply scientific thinking to something you're curious about in your own life.
